newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-CAPELLO'S TRIP PROMPTS TALK OF RETURN TO MILAN.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CAPELLO'S TRIP PROMPTS TALK OF RETURN TO MILAN.

text.p: A two-day trip home was enough to rekindle media speculation on Wednesday that Real Madrid's Italian coach Fabio Capello will rejoin his former club AC Milan next season.
For several weeks, Italian commentators have suggested that Milan's owner-chairman, media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi, wants to recall Capello in a bid to rejuvenate Milan after a disastrous season.

With six games to play, Milan are 10th in serie A and risk failing to qualify for European competition at the end of a campaign in which they have been knocked out of both the Champions' League and the Italian Cup.
Speaking to reporters at Milan's Linate airport on Tuesday, Capello refused to discuss his future plans.

"I've come back to Milan to see my family and for two days I don't want to talk football... I won't be seeing Berlusconi and I've no intention of discussing Milan's affairs. I am coach to Real and I've got my own problems...
"My future plans are top secret...but until things are absolutely certain I don't want to talk about them either in Italy or in Spain".

But newspapers remain convinced Capello's return trip to Italy was partly motivated by the need to consider the terms of a three-year contract, reportedly offered by Milan, worth an annual $1.8 million dollars.

Milan-based sports daily Gazzetta Dello Sport and daily Corriere Della Sera both highlight a cryptic exchange between Capello and a Milan fan at the airport which the papers suggested was evidence of an imminent return to Italy.
The fan told Capello his return to Milan would be like "reheating old soup". Capello replied: "O.K. then, we'll eat this warmed-up soup".

Both papers drew attention to a reported meeting in Madrid last week between Capello and Marcello Dell'Utri, one of Berlusconi's closest advisors, claiming a copy of a new contract was presented to Capello.
Italian commentators argue Capello will find it impossible to say no to Berlusconi because of a debt he feels he owes him.
Prior to a spectacularly successful five-year spell as Milan coach from 1991-96 Capello had been groomed for a job as sports manager within Berlusconi's Fininvest company.
If Capello is called in to take over at Milan next season the move will represent yet another painful reverse for current Milan coach Arrigo Sacchi.
Winner of one Italian league title and two Champions Cups as Milan coach from 1987-91, Sacchi proved highly controversial as national team coach from 1991-96.
Sacchi's return to Milan this season has not brought miracles.
Milan have won six, lost seven and drawn four of their 17 serie A matches under his leadership and were recently humiliated 6-1 at home to Juventus and 3-1 to city rivals Internazionale.
